articles.title: Apple Must Answer Shareholder Questions on Forced Labor, SEC Says
articles.summary: The U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission denied Apple Inc.'s request to block a shareholder proposal seeking greater transparency on its efforts to prevent forced labor in its supply chain. This means Apple will face a vote on the proposal at its next annual shareholder meeting. The request asks for details on identified risk suppliers and actions taken against them.
articles.source: VOA - Voice of America English News

articles.title: Moody's gives Apple top 'AAA' credit rating on growth promise
articles.summary: Ratings agency Moody's upgraded Apple Inc.'s long-term credit rating to 'AAA' with a stable outlook, citing its exceptional liquidity and robust earnings. This places Apple in an elite group of companies with the highest rating. While Apple's financial performance was strong in fiscal 2021, the company faces execution risks from short product cycles, shifting consumer preferences, and supply chain management.

articles.title: 5 things to know about Oracle after $28.3 billion acquisition of Kansas City’s Cerner
articles.summary: Oracle has announced a $28.3 billion acquisition of Cerner Corp., Kansas City's largest private employer, marking one of the year's biggest deals. This move signifies Oracle's growing push into the healthcare industry, following similar expansions by other tech giants. The acquisition brings together Oracle, an $280 billion company with 133,000 employees globally, and Cerner, valued at $23 billion with 28,000 employees worldwide, notably 13,000 in Kansas City.

articles.title: About IBS Bulgaria
articles.summary: IBS Bulgaria is helping regional banks modernize their critical systems to comply with the PSD2 directive. They developed a new open banking platform powered by IBM API Connect and IBM Cloud Pak for Integration technology, resulting in reduced integration times and significant cost reductions for their clients. This solution allows banks to quickly adapt to new regulations and services, with approximately 90% of open banking in Bulgaria now relying on IBM integration technology.

articles.title: Cerner could be acquired by Oracle, says WSJ
articles.summary: Oracle is reportedly in talks to acquire health IT giant Cerner Corp. for an estimated $30 billion, which would be Oracle's largest acquisition to date. This move would significantly bolster Oracle's presence in healthcare technology, particularly in cloud computing and AI, following a trend of major tech companies investing heavily in healthcare-focused firms. The potential acquisition comes amidst a challenging year for Cerner, despite its CEO expressing optimism about long-term growth.

articles.title: Intel to invest $7 billion in new plant in Malaysia, creating 9,000 jobs
articles.summary: Intel Chief Executive Pat Gelsinger announced a $7 billion investment to build a new chip-packaging and testing factory in Malaysia, creating over 4,000 Intel jobs and more than 5,000 construction jobs. This expansion aims to address the global semiconductor shortage, which Gelsinger expects to persist into 2023. The new advanced packaging facility is projected to begin production in 2024.

articles.title: The Invesco QQQ Stock Price Is Up 23.7% Since January. Could There Be More Gains?
articles.summary: The Invesco QQQ Trust (NASDAQ: QQQ) has seen its stock price rise 23.7% since January, driven by major tech companies like Apple and Google, despite recent pullbacks. Investors are closely watching the Federal Reserve's monetary policy meeting for potential hawkish policies that could further impact the Nasdaq index and the QQQ ETF. While the ETF is currently in a downtrend, its present stock price may be attractive for a future rally, though a clear upward trend based on EMA crossings is yet to materialize.

articles.title: Go With GINN as High-Margin Companies Remain Trendy
articles.summary: Investors are expected to favor quality, high-margin companies in 2022, a trend supported by the Goldman Sachs Innovate Equity ETF (GINN). GINN tracks companies with robust profitability, strong earnings growth, and effective margin management, aligning with Goldman Sachs' recommendation for clients. Several of GINN's holdings, including Alphabet, Meta Platforms, Apple, Marvell Technology, Mastercard, PayPal, Autodesk, and Etsy, are featured on Goldman's list of high-margin companies.

articles.title: Apple's App Store broke competition laws, Dutch watchdog says
articles.summary: The Netherlands' competition regulator, ACM, has found that Apple Inc. broke competition laws with its App Store payment policies, specifically concerning dating apps. Apple is ordered to allow alternative payment systems for dating apps and faces a fine of up to 50 million euros if it fails to comply by January 15. Apple has stated it disagrees with the order and has filed an appeal.

articles.title: Apple’s Next Step in Services Could Be New Bundles, Deeper Integration
articles.summary: Apple's future services strategy is expected to focus on deeper integration among its existing offerings and the introduction of new bundles, building on the success of its services division. This push includes the hiring of Facebook's AR/VR communications chief, signaling potential new product categories like headsets. The article also notes the impact of rising Covid cases on Apple's retail operations and its plans for CES.

articles.title: Apple’s long-term credit rating upgraded to AAA by Moody’s
articles.summary: Moody’s Investors Service upgraded Apple Inc.’s long-term credit rating to Aaa, placing it in an exclusive group with Microsoft and Johnson & Johnson as the only U.S. S&P 500 corporations with the highest possible credit score. This upgrade reflects Apple's exceptional liquidity, robust earnings, and strong business profile, as the company continues to focus on a net cash-neutral position and expand into new markets like augmented reality and cars. Despite potential chip-related supply shortages impacting revenue, investors remain optimistic about Apple's long-term prospects.

articles.title: What Zoom’s $85m class action lawsuit means for data privacy
articles.summary: Zoom has agreed to pay an $85 million settlement in a class action lawsuit alleging it shared user data without consent and falsely claimed end-to-end encryption. This case highlights a broader data privacy movement forcing companies to increase transparency and adjust to stricter regulations. Experts believe the lawsuit serves as a cautionary tale for the digital ecosystem and will prompt other companies to re-evaluate their data protection policies.

articles.title: Is Saudi Aramco Stock a Good Buy? • (TADAWUL: 2222)
articles.summary: This article analyzes whether Saudi Aramco stock is a good buy, considering its status as one of the world's largest companies, financial performance, and future outlook. It provides guidance on how to gain exposure to the stock through ETFs, discusses its stock history and value, and presents both bull and bear cases from analysts. The article concludes with a "hold" recommendation due to uncertainties in the global economy and the stock's relatively muted performance despite strong oil prices.

articles.title: Amazon silenced criticism of Xi to do business in China: Report
articles.summary: A Reuters report alleges that Amazon.com Inc. quieted criticism of President Xi Jinping's book on its Chinese platform to maintain business in China. This involved scrubbing negative ratings and reviews for "The Governance of China" following requests from Beijing. This situation mirrors cases of other US companies like Apple and contrasts with others like Yahoo! and LinkedIn that have exited the Chinese market due to a challenging business environment.

articles.title: Apple Should Make a Giant iPad as Its Smart Home Portal
articles.summary: After testing Amazon's new Echo Show 15, the author suggests Apple Inc. (AAPL) should develop a larger iPad to serve as a smart home hub. This move would enhance Apple's presence in the smart home market and diversify the utility of its iPad line. The article also touches on other Apple-related news, including COVID-19 disruptions and internal company changes.

articles.title: |Product Liability & Mass Torts Digest
articles.summary: |A Texas District Court has allowed a class-action lawsuit against Apple to proceed after a plaintiff, Robert Franklin, claimed his iPhone 6 exploded and injured him. The court ruled that Franklin had standing to represent a class of iPhone 6 owners who experienced similar issues, despite Apple's arguments against "substantially similar" products and lack of a safer alternative design. While the design defect claim was dismissed with leave to amend, claims for manufacturing defect, market defect, negligence, and certain Texas Deceptive Trade Practices Act claims were allowed to go forward.
